tn.ref: my heart trembles ... it is moved out of its place
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize the intensity of his fear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: my heart trembles at this
tn.text: The word "this" refers to the storm in [[:en:bible:notes:job:36:32|36:33]].

tn.ref: it is moved out of its place
tn.text: Elihu speaks of his heart beating violently as if it were to jump out of his chest. AT: "it moves out of its place" or "it beats violently" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the noise of his voice, the sound that goes out from his mouth
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. Elihu speaks of the thunder as if it is God's voice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: to the borders of the earth
tn.text: Elihu speaks of the farthest places on the earth as if they were the earth's borders. AT: "everywhere in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: A voice roars after it ... the voice of his majesty
tn.text: Elihu continues to speak of the thunder as if it is God's voice. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: roars after it
tn.text: "roars after the lightning"

tn.ref: the voice of his majesty
tn.text: "his majestic voice"

tn.ref: when his voice is heard
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "when people hear his voice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: likewise to the rain shower
tn.text: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. AT: "likewise, he says to the rain shower" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: He stops the hand of every man
tn.text: Here the word "hand" represents the entire person. AT: "He stops every man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: The storm comes from its chamber in the south and the cold from the scattering winds in the north
tn.text: In Israel, strong wind storms blow in from the south and cold weather approaches from the north. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The storm comes from its chamber in the south
tn.text: Elihu speaks of the storm blowing in from the south as if the storm has a place where it resides until it comes. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: By the breath of God ice is given
tn.text: Elihu speaks of the cold north wind as if it were God's breath. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God's breath makes ice" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: frozen like metal
tn.text: Elihu compares the hardness of ice to the hardness of metal. AT: "frozen, as hard as metal" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: he weighs down the thick cloud with moisture
tn.text: Elihu speaks of God causing the storm clouds to be full of water as if the moisture weighed heavily on the clouds. AT: "he causes the thick clouds to be full of moisture" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: sometimes it happens for correction
tn.text: The word "correction" can be translated with a verbal phrase. The object of his "correction" is people. AT: "sometimes it happens to correct his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: sometimes for his land
tn.text: This means that the rain waters the ground and causes vegetation to grow. AT: "sometimes to water the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Do you know how God forces his will on the clouds and makes the lightning bolts to flash in them?
tn.text: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job cannot know this. AT: "You cannot understand how God forces his will on the clouds and makes the lightning bolts to flash in them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: forces his will on the clouds
tn.text: "controls the clouds" or "makes the clouds obey him"

tn.ref: Do you understand the floating of the clouds, the marvelous deeds of God, who is perfect in knowledge?
tn.text: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job does not know these things. AT: "You do not understand the floating of the clouds, the marvelous deeds of God, who is perfect in knowledge." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the floating of the clouds
tn.text: "how the clouds float"

tn.ref: the marvelous deeds of God
tn.text: The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. AT: "or do you understand the marvelous deeds of God" or "and you do not understand the marvelous deeds of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: Do you understand how your garments become hot ... from the south?
tn.text: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job does not know these things. AT: "You do not understand how your garments become hot ... from the south." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: how your garments become hot
tn.text: "how you become hot in your clothes" or "how you sweat in your clothes"

tn.ref: because the wind comes from the south
tn.text: In Israel, hot winds blow in across the desert from the south and cause hot temperatures. AT: "because of the hot, dry wind blowing in from the south" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Can you spread out the sky ... a mirror of cast metal?
tn.text: Elihu asks this question to emphasize that Job cannot do this. AT: "You cannot spread out the sky ... a mirror of cast metal." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: as strong as a mirror of cast metal
tn.text: In biblical days, mirrors were made of metal. Elihu speaks of the sky giving no rain as if it were as hard as solid metal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: cast metal
tn.text: This refers to metal that is melted, poured into a mold, and then hardens as it cools.

tn.ref: Teach us what we should say to him
tn.text: Here the words "us" and "we" refer to Elihu, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar, but not to Job. Elihu uses this phrase sarcastically. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: because of the darkness of our minds
tn.text: Elihu speaks of the inability to understand as if it were having darkness in one's mind. AT: "because we do not understand" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Should he be told that I wish to speak with him?
tn.text: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one can do this. AT: "I cannot have someone tell him that I wish to speak with him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Should he be told
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Should I have someone tell him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Would a person wish to be swallowed up?
tn.text: Elihu asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that no one would want this to happen. AT: "No person would want to be swallowed up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: to be swallowed up
tn.text: Elihu speaks of a person being destroyed as if the person were swallowed up. This can be stated in active form. AT: "for God to destroy him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Out of the north comes golden splendor
tn.text: The phrase "golden splendor" describes God's glory. This can be made explicit in translation. AT: "God comes from the north with golden splendor" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: over God is fearsome majesty
tn.text: The word "fearsome" means that it causes fear. Elihu speaks of God's majesty as if it were something that rests upon God. AT: "God's majesty causes people to fear" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: we cannot find him
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "we cannot approach him" or 2) this is a metaphor in which Elihu speaks of a person's being unable to fully understand God as if he could not find God. AT: "we cannot comprehend him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: those who are wise in their own minds
tn.text: Here "minds" represents the person's thoughts. AT: "those who are wise in their own thinking" or "those who consider themselves to be wise" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
